fields.gameplay:
First Guesser: The most honest player starts as the first "Guesser." The Guesser turns around, facing away from the group.

Choosing Cards: Without looking at the cards, the other players secretly choose a Truth Card or a Lie Card.

Reading Statements: The Guesser turns back around, and each player reads the statement on their card.

Deciding: The Guesser decides whether each statement is true or a lie. If they believe a statement is false, they place a Finger Card in front of that player1.

Rotating Turns: The role of the Guesser rotates clockwise around the table.

Winning Finger Cards: If the Guesser correctly identifies a Lie Card, they take a Finger Card from the center pile. If they incorrectly identify a Truth Card as a Lie, they must return a Finger Card to the center pile1.

End of Game: The game ends when all Finger Cards are used up. The player with the most Finger Cards wins the game1.
fields.name: You are a Liar
fields.objective: The goal is to be the player with the most Finger Cards at the end of the game.
fields.setup:
up
Players: 3 or more players.

Cards: Sort the cards into three piles: Truth Cards, Lie Cards, and Finger Cards. Place the Truth Cards and Lie Cards face down in the center, and place the Finger Cards next to them1.

Starting Finger Card: Each player is given one Finger Card to start.
fields.tips_and_strategies:
Pay Attention: Listen carefully to the statements and try to detect inconsistencies.

Bluff Wisely: Mix truthful plays with lies to keep other players guessing.

Stay Calm: Keep a straight face and don't give away your intentions.

fields.gameplay:
Host's Turn: The host secretly writes a five-letter word on their secret word board and flips it over.

Guessing: Each player secretly writes a guess on their board.

Clue Marking: The host marks each guess with green chips for correct letters in the correct position, yellow chips for correct letters in the wrong position, and leaves letters not in the word unmarked.

Announcement: The host announces the number of green and yellow chips for each guess but does not reveal specific letters.

Additional Guesses: Players can make additional guesses based on the clues given.

Winning: The first player to correctly guess the word wins the round.

Points: Players earn 1 point for each guess they make.

Winning: The player with the fewest points at the end of the game wins.
fields.name: Wordle
fields.objective: The goal is to guess the five-letter word chosen by the host in as few guesses as possible.
fields.setup:
Players: Gather 3 or more players.

Materials: Each player needs a board, a dry-erase marker, and a shield to hide their guesses from other players.

Host: Choose one player to be the host for the first round.
fields.tips_and_strategies:
Time Limit: You can add a time limit for each guess to speed up the game.

Fast Mode: Players race to solve the word first, with the first correct guess earning 1 point and others earning 0 points.

fields.gameplay:
Players: Two players, each chooses a color.

Turn Order: Players take turns dropping one of their colored discs from the top into any of the seven columns.

Dropping Discs: The disc will fall down and occupy the lowest available space within the column.

Winning the Game: The game ends when one player forms a line of four of their own discs. The line can be horizontal, vertical, or diagonal.

Draw: If the board fills up completely without any player forming a line of four, the game is a draw.
fields.name: Connect Four
fields.objective: The goal is to be the first player to connect four of your own colored discs in a row â€“ horizontally, vertically, or diagonally.
fields.setup:
Game Board: The board is a vertical grid with 6 rows and 7 columns.

Discs: Each player has a set of colored discs (traditionally red and yellow).
fields.tips_and_strategies:
Block Your Opponent: Always be on the lookout for potential winning moves your opponent might make and block them.

Create Multiple Opportunities: Try to create multiple ways to connect four, forcing your opponent to block in two places at once.

Control the Center: Dominating the center column gives you more opportunities to create connecting lines.

fields.gameplay:
Face-Off: The host reads a question, and one player from each team tries to guess the most popular answer. The player who guesses the highest-ranked answer wins control of the round for their team.

Team Play: The team that wins the face-off takes turns guessing the remaining answers on the board. If they guess incorrectly three times, control passes to the other team.

Stealing: The other team gets one chance to guess any remaining answers. If they guess correctly, they steal the points for that round.

Scoring: Points are awarded based on the number of people who gave each answer in the survey. The team with the most points at the end of the game wins.
fields.name: Family Feud Card Game
fields.objective: The goal is to score the most points by guessing the most popular answers to survey questions.
fields.setup:
Players: Divide into two teams.

Cards: Shuffle the question cards and place them in a stack.

Host: Choose one player to be the host. The host reads the questions and keeps track of the scores.
fields.tips_and_strategies:
Fast Money: For a fun twist, play a Fast Money round where two players from the winning team answer five questions each within a time limit.

House Rules: Feel free to add your own rules to make the game more interesting for your group.

fields.gameplay:
Taking Turns: Players take turns rolling the dice and moving their tokens around the board. You can move horizontally or vertically but not diagonally.

Making Suggestions: When you enter a room, you can make a suggestion to determine the suspect, weapon, and room. For example, "I suggest it was Mr. Green in the Library with the Candlestick." Move the suspect and weapon tokens into that room.

Disproving Suggestions: Other players must try to disprove the suggestion by showing you one of the cards you mentioned if they have it. This helps you eliminate possibilities.

Making Accusations: When you're confident you know the solution, you can make an accusation. State your guess about the suspect, weapon, and room. Then, secretly look at the cards in the case file envelope.

Winning the Game: If your accusation is correct, you win the game. If it's incorrect, you're out of the game, but you must continue disproving other players' suggestions.
fields.name: Clue
fields.objective: The goal is to determine who committed the murder, with what weapon, and in which room.
fields.setup:
Game Board: Place the game board in the center of the table. It represents the floor plan of a mansion with various rooms.

Cards: Separate the cards into three piles: suspects, weapons, and rooms. Shuffle each pile separately.

Case File: Randomly select one card from each pile (suspect, weapon, and room) and place them in the case file envelope without looking at them. These cards represent the solution to the murder.

Deal Cards: Shuffle the remaining cards together and deal them to the players.

Player Tokens: Each player chooses a character token and places it on the corresponding starting space on the board.

Weapons: Place the weapon tokens in different rooms on the board.
fields.tips_and_strategies:
Take Notes: Use the provided detective notepad to keep track of the clues and eliminate possibilities.

Be Observant: Pay attention to the cards shown by other players and deduce the hidden cards.

Strategic Movement: Move to rooms strategically to make suggestions and gather information.

fields.gameplay:
Starting Player: The oldest player goes first and becomes the Reader.

Rolling the Category Die: The Reader rolls the category die to determine the category of the first question (Blue is What Am I?, Green is Where Am I?, Orange is Who Am I?, and Red is Hard Ass).

Selecting a Question Card: The Reader selects a question card from the chosen category and reads the first clue aloud.

Answering: Any player can shout out an answer at any time after a clue is read. Each player gets only one try per question.

Correct Answer: If a player answers correctly, they roll the movement die and move their playing piece forward the number of spaces shown.

Incorrect Answer: If a player answers incorrectly, they are out of that round and cannot try again.

Continuing Clues: The Reader continues to read clues until a player answers correctly or all clues are read.

Winning the Round: If no player answers correctly after all clues are read, the Reader wins the round and moves their piece forward.

Next Player: Play passes to the left, and the next player becomes the Reader.

Special Spaces: The game board has special spaces:

Dumb Ass Space: The player landing here is silenced for the next round.

Hard Ass Space: The Reader selects a bonus question from the Hard Ass category for the player landing here. If answered correctly, the player rolls again for a bonus move.

Kick Ass Space: The player landing here moves back three spaces.

The first player to reach "The End" of the Smart Ass's rear end wins the game.
fields.name: Smart Ass
fields.objective: The goal is to be the first player to reach the end of the game board by correctly answering trivia questions.
fields.setup:
Game Board: Place the game board on a flat surface.

Question Cards: Sort the question cards into four categories: What Am I?, Where Am I?, Who Am I?, and Hard Ass. Place each deck in its designated spot on the board.

Playing Pieces: Each player chooses a playing piece and places it at the "Start" space.

Dice: Have the category die and the movement die ready.
fields.tips_and_strategies:
Quick Thinking: Be ready to shout out answers quickly.

Listen Carefully: Pay attention to the clues to make informed guesses.

Stay Calm: Keep a clear mind and don't rush your answers too much.

fields.gameplay:
Drawing Tiles: The first player draws two letter tiles from the bag and shows them to all players.

Word Challenge: Either players race to shout out a word that starts with the first letter and ends with the second letter shown on the tiles. For example, if the tiles show "B" and "T," players might shout out "bat," "bit," or "but." Or, players write down their words, the one with the most words at the end of 60 seconds wins.

Winning the Tiles: Either the first player to correctly shout out a valid word wins the tiles or the player with the most words wins.

Turns: Play passes to the next player, who then draws two new tiles and repeats the process.

Winning the Game: The game continues until a predetermined number of rounds or until a player collects a set number of tiles. The player with the most tiles at the end of the game wins.
fields.name: Smart Mouth
fields.objective: The goal is to collect the most tiles by being the first to shout out a valid word that starts with the first letter and ends with the second letter shown on the tiles.
fields.setup:
Tiles: Place the letter tiles in a bag or container.

Players: 2 or more players.

Starting Player: Decide who goes first.
fields.tips_and_strategies:
Quick Thinking: Practice coming up with words quickly to gain an advantage.

Vocabulary: Expand your vocabulary to have more word options available.

Stay Calm: Keep a clear mind and don't rush your answers too much.

fields.gameplay:
Deal Cards: Shuffle the playing cards and deal a hand of cards to each player (the number of cards depends on the number of players).

Place Markers: Each player places their marker chips on the corresponding spaces on the board for the two corners of their color.

Turn Sequence: Players take turns playing cards and placing marker chips on the board.

Play a Card: On your turn, play a card from your hand and place one of your marker chips on the corresponding space on the board.

Special Cards: Jack cards allow you to remove an opponentâ€™s marker chip from the board, and Two-Eyed Jack cards allow you to place a marker chip on any open space on the board.

Draw a Card: After playing a card, draw a new card from the deck to replenish your hand.

Winning the Game: The game continues until one player successfully creates a sequence of five connected markers on the board. The sequence can be horizontal, vertical, or diagonal1. The first player to do so wins the game.
fields.name: Sequence
fields.objective: The goal is to create rows, columns, or diagonals of five connected markers of your color on the game board.
fields.setup:
Game Board: Place the game board in the center of the table. The board is a 10x10 grid with spaces representing playing cards1.

Playing Cards: Use a standard deck of 52 playing cards, excluding the jokers.

Marker Chips: Each player gets marker chips of a distinct color.

Score Cards: Use score cards to keep track of the gameâ€™s progress.
fields.tips_and_strategies:
Plan Ahead: Anticipate opponentsâ€™ moves and plan your strategy accordingly.

Block Opponents: Try to block opponents from creating sequences while building your own.

Utilize Special Cards: Use Jack and Two-Eyed Jack cards strategically to gain positional advantage.

fields.gameplay:
Starting Player: Choose a starting player. This player makes a "Never Have I Ever" statement. For example, "Never have I ever gone skydiving."

Responses: Players who have done the action mentioned must take a drink (if playing as a drinking game) or put a finger down (if playing with points).

Next Player: The turn passes clockwise to the next player, who makes a new "Never Have I Ever" statement.

Elimination (Optional): If playing with points, players who put down all their fingers are out of the game. The last player remaining wins.
fields.name: Never Have I Ever Card Game
fields.objective: The goal is to have fun and learn interesting facts about the players. The game can be played as a drinking game or with points.
fields.setup:
Players: 4 or more players.

Cards (Optional): If you have a deck of "Never Have I Ever" cards, shuffle and place them in the center. If you don't have cards, you can play without them by coming up with statements on the spot.
fields.tips_and_strategies:
Be Honest: The fun of the game relies on honesty.

Keep It Fun: Choose a mix of lighthearted and interesting statements.

Safe Play: If playing as a drinking game, drink responsibly and know your limits.

fields.gameplay:
Turn Phases: Each turn consists of three phases: draw two train cards, claim a route, and draw destination tickets.

Draw Two Train Cards: You can either take the top card from the face-up cards or draw from the deck. If you take a face-up card, replace it with a new card from the deck.

Claim a Route: Use your train cards to claim a route between two cities on the board. The number of cards you use must match the number of spaces in the route.

Draw Destination Tickets: Draw two more destination tickets and keep at least one.

Winning the Game: The game ends when one player has 2 or fewer train cards left in the deck or when a player has claimed 8 routes. Players then count their points from completed destination tickets and the longest continuous path.
fields.name: Ticket to Ride
fields.objective: The goal is to connect cities on the map by claiming railway routes and score points based on the length of your routes and completed destination tickets.
fields.setup:
Board: Place the game board in the center of the table.

Trains: Each player chooses a color and takes the corresponding set of train cars.

Train Cards: Shuffle the train cards and deal 4 cards to each player. Place the remaining deck face down.

Face-Up Cards: Turn the top 5 cards of the deck face up.

Destination Tickets: Shuffle the destination ticket cards and deal 3 to each player. Players must keep at least 2 tickets and return the rest to the deck.
fields.tips_and_strategies:
Plan Ahead: Think about your destination tickets and plan your routes accordingly.

Block Opponents: Claim routes that might block your opponents from completing their tickets.

Use Locomotives

fields.gameplay:
Exploration Phase: Players take turns exploring the house by moving through rooms, discovering new rooms, and collecting items and omens.

Movement: On their turn, a player can move a number of spaces equal to their current Speed value.

Discovering Rooms: When moving into an unexplored area, draw a Room tile from the stack and connect it to the current room.

Drawing Cards: Some rooms have symbols that indicate drawing a card (Event, Item, or Omen). Follow the instructions on the card1.

Omen Cards and Haunt Roll: When an Omen card is drawn, the player must make a Haunt roll by rolling six dice. If the result is less than the number of Omen cards drawn so far, the Haunt begins1.

Haunt Phase: The Haunt scenario is determined based on the room where the Haunt was triggered and the Omen card that triggered it.

Revealing the Traitor: The Traitorâ€™s Tome is used to determine the Traitor and their objectives. The heroes use the Secrets of Survival book to find their objectives1.

Separate Instructions: The Traitor and the heroes follow their respective instructions to complete their objectives.

The game ends when one side achieves their victory condition as described in the haunt scenario.
fields.name: Betrayal at House on the Hill
fields.objective: The goal is to explore the haunted mansion, survive the haunt, and achieve the goals set by the haunt scenario, either as heroes or the traitor
fields.setup:
Game Components: Gather all the game components, including room tiles, character cards, event cards, item cards, omen cards, dice, tokens, and the Traitorâ€™s Tome and Secrets of Survival haunt books.

Choose Characters: Each player selects a character card and the corresponding figure. There are six character cards, each with two characters to choose from (front and back of the card).

Set Starting Traits: Adjust the plastic clips on the character card to the starting values for Speed, Might, Sanity, and Knowledge.

Place Starting Tiles: Place the Entrance Hall, Foyer, and Grand Staircase tiles in the center of the playing area.

Shuffle Decks: Shuffle the Room tiles, Event cards, Item cards, and Omen cards separately. Place them face down within easy reach of all players.

Determine Player Order: Decide who goes first by any agreed-upon method.
fields.tips_and_strategies:
Teamwork: Work together as heroes to overcome the challenges posed by the haunt.

Communication: Keep communication open to strategize and share information.

Adaptability: Be ready to adapt to the changing dynamics of the game, especially when the haunt begins.

fields.gameplay:
Taking Turns: Players take turns drawing a card from the deck.

Drawing Cards: If you draw a card that is not an Exploding Kitten, you can play any card from your hand or discard it.

Exploding Kittens: If you draw an Exploding Kitten, you must either play a Defuse card to neutralize it or you are out of the game.

Playing Cards: Some cards have special actions, such as skipping a turn, forcing another player to draw two cards, or peeking at the top cards of the deck.

Winning the Game: The last player remaining who hasn't drawn an Exploding Kitten wins the game.
fields.name: Exploding Kittens
fields.objective: The goal is to avoid drawing an Exploding Kitten card and be the last player remaining in the game.
fields.setup:
Remove Exploding Kittens: Take out all the Exploding Kitten cards (usually 4) and set them aside.

Deal Defuse Cards: Give each player one Defuse card (usually 6 Defuse cards in total). These cards can be used to neutralize an Exploding Kitten2.

Shuffle and Deal: Shuffle the remaining deck and deal 7 cards to each player.

Place Exploding Kittens Back: Put the Exploding Kittens back into the deck, one fewer than the number of players. For example, if there are 4 players, put 3 Exploding Kittens back into the deck2.
fields.tips_and_strategies:
Strategic Use of Defuse Cards: Save your Defuse cards for when you draw an Exploding Kitten.

Use Action Cards Wisely

fields.gameplay:
Choose a Card Czar: Select one player to be the Card Czar for the round. The Card Czar is responsible for picking and reading the black card.

Drawing a Black Card: The Card Czar draws a black card and reads the question or fill-in-the-blank statement aloud to the group.

Playing White Cards: The other players choose one (or more, depending on the black card's instructions) of their white cards that they think best completes the statement or answers the question. They pass their chosen white card(s) face down to the Card Czar.

Shuffling and Reading: The Card Czar shuffles the submitted white cards and reads them aloud, ensuring anonymity.

Choosing a Winner: The Card Czar selects the white card they find funniest or most fitting. The player who submitted the chosen card wins the round and keeps the black card as a point.

Next Round: A new player becomes the Card Czar, and the process repeats. Each player draws back up to ten white cards at the end of their turn.

The game continues until a player reaches a predetermined number of black cards (usually 5 or 7), signifying they've won the game.
fields.name: Cards Against Humanity
fields.objective: The goal is to be the first player to win a predetermined number of rounds by playing the funniest or most outrageous answers.
fields.setup:
Players: 4 or more players (the more, the merrier).

Cards: There are two types of cards: black cards and white cards.

Black Cards: These cards contain questions or fill-in-the-blank statements.

White Cards: These cards contain various phrases or words.

Dealing: Each player draws ten white cards.
fields.tips_and_strategies:
House Rules: Feel free to introduce your own house rules to make the game more interesting or better suited to your groupâ€™s sense of humor.

Expansions: Cards Against Humanity has many expansion packs that add new cards and themes to the game.

fields.gameplay:
How to play the boardgame chess
Chess is a classic two-player strategy game that's played on an 8x8 grid board. Hereâ€™s a quick guide on how to play:

Objective
The goal is to checkmate your opponent's king, meaning the king is in a position to be captured ("in check") and there is no legal move to remove the threat.

Setup
Board: Place the board so that each player has a white (or light) square on their right-hand side.

Pieces: Each player has 16 pieces: 1 King, 1 Queen, 2 Rooks, 2 Knights, 2 Bishops, and 8 Pawns.

Setup: Arrange the pieces on the two rows closest to each player. From left to right on the first row: Rook, Knight, Bishop, Queen, King, Bishop, Knight, Rook. Place the pawns on the row in front of the other pieces.

Basic Moves
King: Moves one square in any direction.

Queen: Moves any number of squares in any direction.

Rook: Moves any number of squares horizontally or vertically.

Bishop: Moves any number of squares diagonally.

Knight: Moves in an "L" shape: two squares in one direction and then one square perpendicular. Knights can jump over other pieces.

Pawn: Moves forward one square, or two squares on its first move. Pawns capture diagonally.

Special Moves
Castling: A special move involving the king and a rook. The king moves two squares towards the rook, and the rook moves next to the king. Conditions apply: neither piece can have moved before, there must be no pieces between them, and the king cannot be in check or move through check.

En Passant: If a pawn moves two squares forward from its starting position and lands beside an opponent's pawn, the opponent's pawn can capture it as if it had moved only one square forward.

Pawn Promotion: When a pawn reaches the opponent's back row, it can be promoted to any other piece (except a king), usually a queen.

Winning the Game
Checkmate: The game ends when a player's king is checkmated.

Stalemate: A draw occurs when a player has no legal moves and their king is not in check.

Other Draws: The game can also end in a draw by mutual agreement, threefold repetition, fifty-move rule, or insufficient material to checkmate.
fields.name: Chess
fields.objective: The goal is to checkmate your opponent's king, meaning the king is in a position to be captured ("in check") and there is no legal move to remove the threat.
fields.setup:
Board: Place the board so that each player has a white (or light) square on their right-hand side.

Pieces: Each player has 16 pieces: 1 King, 1 Queen, 2 Rooks, 2 Knights, 2 Bishops, and 8 Pawns.

Setup: Arrange the pieces on the two rows closest to each player. From left to right on the first row: Rook, Knight, Bishop, Queen, King, Bishop, Knight, Rook. Place the pawns on the row in front of the other pieces.
fields.tips_and_strategies:
Control the Center: Dominating the center of the board allows greater mobility for your pieces.

Protect Your King: Always be mindful of threats to your king.

Develop Pieces Early: Bring your knights and bishops into the game early for better control and flexibility.

Think Ahead: Always consider your opponent's potential moves and plan accordingly.

fields.gameplay:
Starting the Game: The player to the left of the dealer goes first. Players take turns in a clockwise direction.

Playing a Card: On your turn, you can play a card from your hand that matches the rank or suit of the top card on the discard pile. For example, if the top card is a 6 of hearts, you can play any 6 or any heart.

Special Card - Crazy Eights: Playing an 8 is special because it allows you to change the current suit to any suit you choose. You do not have to match the rank or suit of the previous card.

Drawing a Card: If you cannot play a card, you must draw one card from the draw pile. If the drawn card can be played, you can play it immediately. If not, your turn ends.

Winning the Game: The first player to get rid of all their cards wins the game. If the draw pile is exhausted and no player has won, reshuffle the discard pile to form a new draw pile and continue playing.
fields.name: Crazy Eights
fields.objective: The goal of Crazy Eights is to be the first player to get rid of all your cards.
fields.setup:
Use a standard 52-card deck.

Players: 2 to 5 players.

Dealing: Deal 5 cards to each player if there are 4 or more players. If there are 2 or 3 players, deal 7 cards each. Place the remaining deck face down to form the draw pile, and turn the top card of the draw pile face up to start the discard pile.
fields.tips_and_strategies:
Keep Track of Eights: Save your eights for strategic moments when you need to change the suit.

Multiple Decks: For larger groups, you can use multiple decks to ensure everyone has enough cards.

Scoring: Some variations include scoring based on the cards left in players' hands when one player goes out.

fields.gameplay:
Asking Questions: The Question Reader draws a question card and reads the question aloud.

Writing Answers: Players write their guesses on their dry-erase boards. Answers are always numerical.

Placing Bets: Players place their chips on the betting mat to indicate their confidence in their own answer or someone else's. You can bet on your own answer or on another player's answer.

Revealing Answers: After the time limit (usually 30 seconds), players reveal their answers.

Sorting Answers: The answers are arranged in order from lowest to highest.

Payouts: Players who bet on the correct answer win chips based on the odds marked on the betting mat. The player with the most chips at the end of the game wins.
fields.name: Witts and Wagers
fields.objective: The goal is to earn the most chips by making accurate guesses and placing smart bets.
fields.setup:
Players: 3 to 7 players.

Components: Each player gets a dry-erase board, a marker, and a set of chips.

Question Reader: Choose one player to be the Question Reader for the first round.
fields.tips_and_strategies:
Know Your Strengths: Bet on questions that you feel confident about.

Read the Room: Pay attention to other players' guesses and bet on answers that seem reasonable but not too extreme.

Spread Your Bets: Don't put all your chips on one guess; spread them out to increase your chances of winning.

fields.gameplay:
Teams: Divide into two teams of two players each. Each team stands behind their row of cups.

Starting the Game:

Decide which team goes first. This can be done with a coin toss, rock-paper-scissors, or "eye-to-eye" where one player from each team attempts to make eye contact while shooting. The first to sink a cup starts the game.

Shooting:

Players take turns throwing the ping pong ball at the opponent's cups. Each player gets one shot per turn. The aim is to land the ball into one of the opponentâ€™s cups.

Scoring:

If the ball lands in a cup, the opposing team must drink the contents of that cup and then remove the cup from the table.

If both players on a team make their shots, they get "balls back" and take another turn.

Re-Racking:

Teams can request to have the cups rearranged into a more compact formation. Typically, each team is allowed to re-rack the cups once per game.

Winning:

The game continues until one team has eliminated all of the opponent's cups. The losing team must then drink the remaining cups on the winning team's side.

The winning team has the option of starting the next game as the first shooters.

House Rules
Many variations and house rules can be added to Beer Pong, such as:

Bouncing: If the ball bounces before landing in a cup, it counts as two cups removed, but the opposing team can swat the ball away.

Redemption: After the last cup is hit, the opposing team gets a chance to shoot until they miss.

Celebrity Shot: Allowing a guest to take a shot on behalf of a player.
fields.name: Beer Pong
fields.objective: The goal of Beer Pong is to throw a ping pong ball across the table and land it in one of your opponent's cups. The first team to eliminate all of the other team's cups wins.
fields.setup:
Equipment:

A standard beer pong table or a regular table (about 8 feet long).

20 plastic cups (10 for each team).

Ping pong balls (at least 2).

Beer or another beverage of your choice.

Arrangement:

Set up 10 cups in a pyramid shape (4-3-2-1) at each end of the table. Fill each cup with a desired amount of beer.

fields.gameplay:
Starting the Game: The player with the Ace of Spades (or any predetermined card) starts the game by placing one or more cards face down in the center and declaring them as a specific rank (e.g., "one Ace").

Taking Turns: Players take turns in a clockwise direction. On your turn, you must play one or more cards face down and declare them as the next rank in sequence (e.g., if the previous player declared Aces, you must declare Twos, then Threes, and so on).

Calling Bullshit: If you think a player is lying about the cards they played, you can call "Bullshit!" The player must then reveal the cards they played:

If they were lying, they must pick up all the cards in the center.

If they were telling the truth, the player who called Bullshit must pick up all the cards in the center.

Winning the Game: The first player to get rid of all their cards wins the game. If a player is caught lying or falsely accuses another player, they must pick up the cards and continue playing.
fields.name: Bullshit
fields.objective: The goal is to be the first player to get rid of all your cards by playing them face down and convincing others that you're telling the truth about what you played.
fields.setup:
Deck: Use a standard 52-card deck. If there are more than 4 players, you might want to use two decks.

Players: 3 or more players.

Dealing: Deal all the cards evenly among the players. Some players might have one more card than others.
fields.tips_and_strategies:
Bluff Wisely: Mix truthful plays with bluffs to keep other players guessing.

Pay Attention: Keep track of the cards that have been played to make informed decisions about when to call Bullshit.

Timing: Choose the right moments to call Bullshit to maximize your chances of catching a lie.

fields.gameplay:
Turn Phases: Each turn consists of three phases: Action, Buy, and Clean-up.

Action Phase: Play Action cards from your hand. These cards allow you to draw more cards, gain coins, attack other players, or manipulate your deck.

Buy Phase: Use Treasure cards to buy cards from the Supply piles. You can only buy one card per turn1.

Clean-up Phase: Discard your hand and draw 5 new cards.

Winning the Game: The game ends when either the Provinces pile is empty or three Supply piles (including Treasure or Victory piles) are empty. Count your victory points from the cards in your deck, and the player with the most points wins1.
fields.name: Dominion
fields.objective: The goal is to have the most victory points in your deck at the end of the game.
fields.setup:
Shuffle Kingdom Cards: Shuffle the Kingdom cards and place 10 face-up cards in the center of the table. These are the available Supply piles1.

Starting Decks: Each player starts with a deck of 7 cards (usually 3 Estates and 4 Coppers). Shuffle your deck and draw 5 cards to form your starting hand2.

Supply Piles: Set aside Treasure cards (Copper, Silver, Gold) and Victory cards (Estates, Duchies, Provinces) in separate piles. Leave the Curse cards face down for now1.
fields.tips_and_strategies:
Strategic Buying: Focus on buying cards that synergize well with each other.

Action Cards: Use Action cards to gain more buying power and control over your deck.

Expansions: Dominion has many expansions that introduce new Kingdom cards with unique abilities, adding variety and replayability to the game.

fields.gameplay:
Taking Turns: Players take turns calling out a grid coordinate (e.g., "B5") to try and hit their opponent's ships.

Recording Hits and Misses:

If the called coordinate contains a part of an opponent's ship, it's a hit. The opponent says "hit" and marks it on their primary grid.

If the coordinate does not contain a ship, it's a miss. The opponent says "miss."

The attacking player marks the result on their tracking grid.

Sinking Ships: When all the coordinates of a ship have been hit, the opponent announces which ship has been sunk (e.g., "You sank my battleship!").

Winning the Game: The game continues until one player sinks all of the opponent's ships, thus winning the game.
fields.name: Battleship
fields.objective: The goal of Battleship is to sink all of your opponent's ships before they sink yours.
fields.setup:
Game Board: Each player has two grids: a primary grid to place their ships and a tracking grid to mark their hits and misses on the opponent's grid.

Ships: Each player places the following ships on their primary grid:

Carrier (5 spaces)

Battleship (4 spaces)

Cruiser (3 spaces)

Submarine (3 spaces)

Destroyer (2 spaces)

Placement: Ships can be placed horizontally or vertically but not diagonally. Ships cannot overlap or extend beyond the grid.
fields.tips_and_strategies:
Strategic Placement: Place your ships in a scattered and unpredictable manner to make it harder for your opponent to find them.

Patterned Attacks: Use systematic search patterns when calling out coordinates to efficiently locate and sink your opponent's ships.

fields.gameplay:
Rolling the Dice: Players take turns rolling the dice and moving their pawns the corresponding number of spaces.

Special Spaces: As you move around the board, you'll land on different spaces that have various actions:

Drink: Take a sip of your drink.

Challenge: Perform a silly dare or answer a question.

Call Out: Call out another player to perform a task or answer a question.

Confession: Share something about yourself or answer a personal question.

Mini Competition: Engage in a quick game or challenge with another player.

Winning the Game
fields.name: Tipsy Land
fields.objective: The goal is to be the first player to reach the end of the board by rolling the dice and moving your pawn.
fields.setup:
Board: Place the game board in the center of the table.

Pawns: Each player chooses a pawn and places it at the start of the board.

Drinks: Have drinks ready for each player. The game can be played with alcoholic or non-alcoholic beverages.
fields.tips_and_strategies:
Have Fun: The game is meant to be lighthearted and fun, so embrace the silliness and enjoy the interactions with your friends.

Be Creative: Feel free to come up with your own dares, challenges, and questions to keep the game interesting.

Stay Safe: If you're playing with alcoholic drinks, make sure to drink responsibly and know your limits.

fields.gameplay:
Turn Order: Players roll two dice to determine turn order. The highest roll goes first.

Rolling Dice: On your turn, roll the dice and move your token the number of spaces shown.

Buying Properties: If you land on an unowned property, you can buy it from the bank. If you decline, the banker auctions it off to the highest bidder.

Paying Rent: If you land on a property owned by another player, you must pay rent to that player according to the property's rent card.

Building: Once you own all the properties of a color group, you can build houses and hotels, increasing rent.

Drawing Cards: If you land on Chance or Community Chest, draw a card and follow its instructions.

Jail: You can go to jail by landing on the "Go to Jail" space, drawing a card that sends you to jail, or rolling doubles three times in a row. You can get out by rolling doubles, using a "Get Out of Jail Free" card, or paying $50.

Bankruptcy: If you owe more money than you can pay, you must declare bankruptcy and are eliminated from the game. The last player remaining wins.
fields.name: Monopoly
fields.objective: The goal is to be the last player remaining with money after all others have gone bankrupt.
fields.setup:
Board: Place the Monopoly board on a flat surface.

Money: Each player starts with $1,500 in various denominations.

Player Tokens: Each player chooses a token and places it on the "GO" space.

Cards: Shuffle the Chance and Community Chest cards and place them face down on their designated spots.

Banker: Choose a player to be the banker, responsible for handling money, property titles, houses, and hotels.
fields.tips_and_strategies:
To speed up the game, consider these variations:

Shorter Game Play: Only play until a pre-determined time limit (e.g., 1 hour). The player with the most assets at the end wins.

Speed Die: Use the optional Speed Die for faster movement around the board.

Free Parking Bonus: Players receive $500 when they land on Free Parking.

Initial Property Distribution: Deal three random properties to each player at the start of the game.

Double Rent on Unmortgaged Properties: Whenever a player lands on an unmortgaged property that is owned by another player, they pay double the rent if the property is already developed with houses or hotels.
